image.altText: A photo of a woman with black and red hair stands outside in a garden with her arm around a young girl. They look concerned.

props.synopsis: Before the cost of living crisis, mother-of-five Bec Cocker used to shop at Australia's two major supermarkets, now she says she shops differently and relies on charities to keep costs down. Others say they bulk shop and grow their own herbs to help, as data shows prices are not coming down.

title.children: Aussie households share how they keep up with high grocery costs

image.altText: ABC Adelaide Collinswood building. Photo taken Feb 13 2025.

props.synopsis: The ABC and South Australian government will investigate relocating the public broadcaster's Adelaide operations to a new central site, with plans to move in 2029.

title.children: ABC to move Adelaide operations out of landmark Collinswood building

image.altText: A large standstone home. A large navy boat is in front of it.

props.synopsis: Coal miners are on paid leave at his mine in NSW and workers at his South Australian steelworks are facing an uncertain future, yet steel baron Sanjeev Gupta is about to renovate his $34 million Sydney home.

title.children: Whyalla faces uncertain future as owner gets approval for $34m mansion renovation

image.altText: A cow standing in a pen being milked.

props.synopsis: 'Voluntary milking systems' — or robots — are not new to the industry, but it's hoped a significant uptake of the technology will entice the next generation of producers to stay in the industry.

title.children: Calm cows and a sleep in for dairy farmers who 'couldn't ask for anything better'

image.altText: Adelaide Youth Court

props.synopsis: A 15-year-old who was arrested after 21 extremist videos were found on her mobile phone and school-issued laptop has avoided a custodial penalty, with a magistrate instead ordering she participate in family conferencing.

title.children: Teen with extremist videos on school laptop 'did not fully appreciate wrongfulness'

image.altText: Letiticia Fortune walks along a paved footpath wearing a long-sleeve shirt and sunglasses.

props.synopsis: Letiticia Fortune has been ordered to stand trial over an alleged attempt to smother Jonathon Hawtin while he was in a rehabilitation centre, after two others allegedly earlier attempted to take his life in an axe attack.

title.children: Woman accused of smothering attempt on paralysed man pleads not guilty

image.altText: Georgie Vermeeren stands in front of a grey background with pink roses and green leaves around her face.

props.synopsis: Australian native flowers, dahlias, and chrysanthemum are overtaking the classic rose as more people across the country seek out locally grown blooms.

title.children: Flower trends shift as Australians buy locally grown blooms

image.altText: A young Caucasian woman with glasses, a white tshirt and brown hair sitting in a cafe

props.synopsis: Gambling among younger Australians is often associated with men making bets online or at the pub with their mates, but research – and the lived experience of young women – shows that is not always the case.

title.children: Ella never thought one bet would cost her thousands, research shows she's not alone

image.altText: A small bus reporposed into motorhome bogged in sand at Aldinga Beach.

props.synopsis: A man who drove his new motorhome onto the sand at Aldinga Beach to watch the sunset woke in the middle of the night to find his converted bus bogged, and waves slapping.

title.children: Bogged motorhome owner woke at 4am 'with the waves slapping into me'

image.altText: A young woman in a black top and jeans looking at demountable classrooms through a metal fence.

props.synopsis: One of Broken Hill's two high schools was shut down following the discovery of hazardous mould. After more than 12 months, the community is frustrated by the lack of action on the promised rebuild.

title.children: School marked for demolition still standing a year after mould outbreak

image.altText: Josh Carr and Ken Hinkley

props.synopsis: Over the past two decades in the AFL, there have been a handful of coaching succession plans delivering mixed results. Port Adelaide must look to the past to figure out what to do and what not to do with its own handover.

title.children: Port to learn from past successions after gambling on Hinkley and Carr

image.altText: Ambulances outside a regional hospital.

props.synopsis: A report by the doctors' union says ambulance ramping is now a common occurrence at Mount Gambier Hospital, and patients and staff are being put at risk. But the state government says an expansion is underway.

title.children: Ramping 'common' at regional SA hospital as issue comes to the country

image.altText: A drying dam with only a small amount of water in a brown, rocky landscape

props.synopsis: Rainwater tanks, dams, and springs are running dry in Adelaide Hills and Fleurieu Peninsula while water carriers say they are struggling to meet the demand from both farmers and households.

title.children: Running out of water after record low rainfall in parts of SA

image.altText: A woman standing next to a barber chair.

props.synopsis: Skills shortages, network connectivity issues and added freight costs are just some of the challenges for business owners in regional Australia — but one business group says it's forcing them to be more innovative.

title.children: Insight into what it's like starting a business in a remote town

image.altText: Smoke rises above hills behind Rosebery

props.synopsis: Communities on Tasmania's west coast are watching the advance of bushfires closely, with light rain providing some relief.

title.children: Bushfire threat to communities on Tasmania's west coast

image.altText: A boy goes to give an excited Albanese a high five in a classroom

props.synopsis: Parents will be guaranteed a minimum three days of subsidised child care regardless of how much they work or study, as parliament passes laws that take a step towards universal childcare.

title.children: Labor teams up with crossbench to guarantee three days of subsidised child care for all

image.altText: Bankstown Hospital nurses Ahmad Rashad Nadir, left, and Sarah Abu Lebdeh, right, leaning in to screen

props.synopsis: The NSW health minister says there is "no evidence" patients have been adversely affected after being treated by two Sydney nurses who spoke about threatening harm to Israeli patients, as police await an unedited version of their conversation with an Israeli content creator.

title.children: Nurses suspended from working in Australia after 'sickening' video

image.altText: Shorten stands speaking in the prime minister's courtyard.

props.synopsis: A speechwriter hired on a $600,000, two-year contract to write speeches for Services Australia and its minister Bill Shorten, has joined him at his new job at the University of Canberra.

title.children: Bill Shorten's $300k speechwriter follows him to University of Canberra

image.altText: A close of a young girl with a shovel of sand

props.synopsis: Authorities provide an update as Cyclone Zelia intensifies to category five system and the Bureau of Meteorology says it is bringing very destructive winds and heavy rain to West Australia's Pilbara.

title.children: Tropical Cyclone Zelia now category 5, 'significant' impact expected in WA

image.altText: Police arrest a man under Strike Force Veritas.

props.synopsis: Seven people have been charged following the discovery of alleged fraudulent sexual abuse compensation claims.

title.children: Seven charged over alleged fraudulent child sex abuse compensation claims

image.altText: A person clutching their stomach.

props.synopsis: Severe abdominal pains, unpredictable bowel movements and fatigue are some of the serious symptoms 180,000 Australians live with every day and new research shows the often stigmatising condition is costing the economy  $7.8 billion a year.

title.children: IBD is invisible, chronic, often stigmatised — and rates are growing

image.altText: Matthew Kuhnemann holds the ball aloft to acknowledge the crowd

props.synopsis: Xavier Doherty defends Matthew Kuhnemann's bowling action while saying the allegations will unfortunately stick with the spinner.

title.children: Former Test spinner says Kuhnemann chucking allegations will 'stick'

props.synopsis: Around-the-clock coverage of news events as they break, at home and abroad.

title.children: Watch: News Channel

image.altText: Commonwealth Bank chief executive Matt Comyn looks at the camera in an office setting.

props.synopsis: Banks are prohibited from telegraphing rates moves in advance, but it doesn't take much reading between the lines to see that an RBA rate cut next week will be passed on in full.

title.children: CBA boss 'acutely aware' customers expect rate cuts to be passed on

image.altText: John Lister wearing a dark coloured polo shirt standing in front of some greenery,.

props.synopsis: Labor candidate John Lister is on track to win the Werribee by-election, having increased his narrow lead with the counting of further postal votes on Thursday.

title.children: Labor poised to retain seat of Werribee following tight by-election race

image.altText: Mobile vision of three shirtless men on a street with a crowd in the background.

props.synopsis: Bali police are searching for a group of foreigners, who attacked security guards with wooden planks during a violent brawl outside Finns Beach Club.

title.children: Tourists and security clash in violent brawl outside popular Bali club

image.altText: A close up image of Kevin Rudd with his hand on his chin.

props.synopsis: Continuing to highlight Labor's past critique of Donald Trump carries political risk for the Coalition. Not least because it ignores what's really driving those encouraging Trump to apply tariffs to Australia.

title.children: Australia's US tariffs problem is more about the Coalition than Kevin Rudd

image.altText: A researcher holds a pipette under a microscope.

props.synopsis: Australian researchers dependent on US funding are facing an uncertain future as the Trump administration attempts to slash funding and slap restrictions on medical and scientific research.

title.children: Trump funding cuts leave Australian researchers in limbo

image.altText: Brielle holds her daughter as she looks off a balcony.

props.synopsis: Apartment living is a key pillar of government plans to ease the housing crisis by densifying well-connected parts of Australia's largest cities. But some have questioned the viability of the plans, saying the current stock of apartments was poorly suited for families.

title.children: Could a high-rise apartment replace the classic family home?

image.altText: Child's hand being held by an adult

props.synopsis: Protection from family violence is a postcode lottery and children should be allowed to apply for their own family violence orders, a parliamentary inquiry into the system has found.

title.children: Should kids get their own family violence orders? This report says yes

image.altText: The female humpback anglerfish was spotted during a shark research expedition.

props.synopsis: The footage was captured on a shark research trip off the Canary Islands.

title.children: Video captures 'black seadevil' swimming near ocean's surface for first time

image.altText: An aboriginal woman with black hair looks at the camera

props.synopsis: Leonie Ebsworth was around 19 years old and enjoying a night at the Empress Hotel in Redfern, New South Wales, when a man approached her and said the impossible.

title.children: 'You're my sister': The words that untangled a stolen childhood

image.altText: A woman walks across a parking lot.

props.synopsis: Police searching for missing Queensland mum Tayla Spies hope information from the public can help them narrow down a vast search area and ultimately find the 29-year-old.

title.children: New footage shows last known movements of missing mum

image.altText: A person clutching their stomach.

props.synopsis: Severe abdominal pains, unpredictable bowel movements and fatigue are some of the serious symptoms 180,000 Australians live with every day and new research shows the often stigmatising condition is costing the economy  $7.8 billion a year.

title.children: IBD is invisible, chronic, often stigmatised — and rates are growing

image.altText: A bell towel of an Orthodox church in the town of Oia on the island of Santorini, Greece

props.synopsis: Santorini, hit by an earthquake in late January, has since been shaken by a swarm of tremors. Most of its 16,000 residents have fled, and authorities have declared a state of emergency on nearby Amorgos as the quakes continue.

title.children: What's next for Greek tourism hotspot rattled by an 'earthquake swarm'
